original.title: Classifiquei 126 Decisoes em Two-Way/One-Way Door e Lancei Banco Digital em 11 Meses
original.title_pt: Classifiquei 126 Decisoes em Two-Way/One-Way Door e Lancei Banco Digital em 11 Meses
original.title_en: Classified 126 Decisions as Two-Way/One-Way Door and Launched Digital Bank in 11 Months

pt.s:
"10 minutos contra 27 dias — estamos perdendo o mercado." O alerta que recebi em janeiro de 2016 era brutal: concorrentes digitais abriam contas em menos de 10 minutos enquanto nossa rota de aprovação levava 27 dias e sangrava 38% dos leads. O board queria plano completo em 18 meses, mas esse ritmo faria a Amazon e novos bancos capturarem os 420 mil potenciais correntistas do pipeline antes do Next chegar ao mercado. Eu precisava agir em semanas, não meses.

O maior bloqueio não era tecnologia — era a cultura institucional de 'tudo precisa de 3 comitês e 6 semanas'. Ninguém havia diferenciado decisões reversíveis de irreversíveis. Stakes eram mortais: perder R$ 310M em saldo projetado no primeiro ano, assistir ao Nubank dominar nosso público-alvo (18-35 anos) e ver minha carreira como líder de inovação ir para o ralo. Eu criei o SeDR (Speedy Decision Review): framework revolucionário de classificação de decisões em two-way door (reversíveis, baixo custo de rollback) vs. one-way door (irreversíveis, alto impacto). Identifiquei que 79% das 126 decisões mapeadas eram two-way door e podiam ser tomadas em menos de 24h. Esse framework quebrou 70 anos de paradigma de lentidão institucional do Bradesco.
pt.t: O desafio crítico que enfrentei foi transformar uma cultura de lentidão em velocidade controlada. Eu era o single-threaded owner da trilha de Produto e Tecnologia do Next, com autonomia para definir escopo, cronograma e abordagem de risco. Minha responsabilidade pessoal era reduzir o time-to-market para 11 meses sem comprometer conformidade e proteger a jornada do cliente.
pt.a:
Minha abordagem foi criar um mecanismo permanente de decisão rápida com controle de risco.

Primeiro eu estruturei uma sala de decisao diaria com oito executivos e lancei o mecanismo "SeDR" (Speedy Decision Review) que eu mesmo conduzia. Eu classifiquei 126 decisoes em two-way door ou one-way door; 79% foram aprovadas em menos de 24 horas. Para decisoes two-way door, criei fast-track: apresentacao de 1 pagina, 3 criterios (impacto cliente, reversibilidade <30 dias, custo rollback <20% do total), aprovacao em ate 24h. Exemplo: integracao com ClearSale (antifraud) foi aprovada em 9 horas porque impacto cliente era alto, mas poderiamos trocar de provider em 2 semanas se necessario - custo de rollback seria apenas R$15k (1.2% do orcamento).

Para decisoes one-way door, exigi analise profunda: 3 cenarios, impacto 5 anos, exit strategy, aprovacao com VP+CTO. Exemplo: escolha de core bancario (Temenos) levou 4 semanas de analise porque migracao custaria R$8M e 18 meses. O CFO inicialmente discordou do uso de KYC light e queria aguardar parecer externo. Eu levei a ele a analise de risco baseada em 420 mil leads e consegui autorizacao condicionada aos gatilhos que defini.

Em paralelo eu redesenhei o funil de abertura removendo 17 campos redundantes e integrei a API antifraude da ClearSale em nove dias, reduzindo revisao manual de 82% para 41%. Para garantir rollback eu defini corte automatico quando erro documental superasse 4% em qualquer hora e deixei scripts prontos. Eu tambem criei com o time de pagamentos um painel em tempo real que eu auditava quatro vezes por dia, monitorando SLA de cartao virtual, latencia de liquidacao e NPS transacional. Com esse comando central eu aprovei 32 feature toggles, bloqueei 11 solicitacoes de escopo que atrasariam o MVP e liberei squads para testar com clientes piloto em 48 horas.
pt.r:
O impacto mensurável para os clientes — 420 mil leads no pipeline transformados em 1.2 milhão de clientes ativos — foi transformador.

O Next entrou em producao no mes 11, 7 meses antes do plano original. O onboarding digital caiu de 27 dias para 10 minutos e a taxa de abandono despencou de 38% para 9%. Ao longo dos primeiros 12 meses, 1,2 milhao de clientes ativos geraram R$310 mi em saldo medio. O NPS da jornada de abertura subiu de 34 para 57 e o tempo de emissao do cartao virtual caiu de 4h para 6 minutos.

Especificamente sobre decisoes: 79% das decisoes (two-way door) foram aprovadas em menos de 24h vs. 6 semanas antes; 94% das decisoes two-way door foram corretas (apenas 6 rollbacks necessarios em 99 decisoes); economia de 147 dias-pessoa em comites desnecessarios. Os modelos de risco mantiveram inadimplencia 0,4 p.p. abaixo da carteira tradicional e nenhum incidente critico ocorreu. A estrutura SeDR foi adotada em 5 outras unidades do Bradesco e virou politica corporativa para programas acima de R$50 mi.
pt.l:
A lição principal desse caso transformou minha abordagem de gestão: velocidade exige mecanismos visíveis e gatilhos objetivos.

O SeDR framework revolucionou minha forma de gerenciar decisões: (1) 80% das decisoes sao two-way door e merecem velocidade, nao perfeicao; (2) Classificar decisoes ANTES de discutir agiliza reunioes em 60%; (3) Criterio de reversibilidade (<30 dias, <20% custo) e mais util que severidade de impacto; (4) Registrar decisoes two-way door com reasoning ajuda rollback rapido se necessario.

Passei a iniciar programas com matriz two-way door, painel de telemetria minima e compromisso contratual de 24 horas para qualquer decisao reversivel. Apliquei SeDR em 3 projetos posteriores (Huawei, Unimed, Sicredi) com economia media de 40% no ciclo de decisao. Usei esse metodo depois na Unimed para acelerar pilotos de IA, liberando experimentos em 45 dias com o mesmo controle de risco.

en.s:
"10 minutes versus 27 days — we're losing the market." The alert I received in January 2016 was brutal: digital competitors were opening accounts in under 10 minutes while our approval path took 27 days and bled 38% of leads. The board wanted an 18-month full plan, yet at that pace Amazon and new banks would capture the 420k prospects in our pipeline before Next reached the market. I had to move within weeks, not months.

The biggest blocker wasn't technology—it was the institutional culture of '3 committees and 6 weeks for everything'. No one had differentiated reversible from irreversible decisions. Stakes were lethal: lose R$310M in projected first-year balance, watch Nubank dominate our target audience (18-35 years), and see my career as innovation leader go down the drain. I created the SeDR (Speedy Decision Review): a revolutionary framework to classify decisions as two-way door (reversible, low rollback cost) vs. one-way door (irreversible, high impact). I identified that 79% of the 126 mapped decisions were two-way door and could be made in under 24h. This framework broke 70 years of Bradesco institutional slowness paradigm.
en.t: The critical challenge I faced was transforming a culture of slowness into controlled speed. I was the single-threaded owner for Product and Technology, empowered to define scope, cadence, and risk posture. My personal mandate was to compress time-to-market to 11 months without breaking compliance or the customer journey.
en.a:
My approach was to create a permanent rapid-decision mechanism with risk control.

I created a daily decision room with eight key leaders and introduced the "SeDR" (Speedy Decision Review) mechanism that I chaired. I classified 126 decisions as two-way or one-way; 79% were cleared within 24 hours. For two-way door decisions, I created a fast-track: 1-page presentation, 3 criteria (customer impact, reversibility <30 days, rollback cost <20% of total), approval within 24h. Example: ClearSale integration (antifraud) was approved in 9 hours because customer impact was high, but we could switch providers in 2 weeks if needed - rollback cost would be only R$15k (1.2% of budget).

For one-way door decisions, I required deep analysis: 3 scenarios, 5-year impact, exit strategy, VP+CTO approval. Example: core banking choice (Temenos) took 4 weeks of analysis because migration would cost R$8M and 18 months. I negotiated directly with the CRO a low-risk onboarding pilot across five customer segments covering 42% of the target base.

I rewired the onboarding funnel, stripping 17 redundant fields, and integrated ClearSale fraud scoring in nine days, cutting manual review from 82% to 41%. I defined rollback triggers whenever document errors exceeded 4% in any hour. I built a live telemetry dashboard with the payments squad and personally checked it four times per day, tracking virtual card SLA, settlement latency, and real-time NPS. Using that command center I greenlit 32 feature toggles and halted 11 scope requests that would have delayed the MVP.
en.r:
The measurable impact for customers — 420k leads in pipeline transformed into 1.2 million active customers — was transformative.

Next went live in month 11, seven months ahead of the original roadmap. Digital onboarding dropped from 27 days to 10 minutes and abandonment fell from 38% to 9%. In the first 12 months we activated 1.2 million customers and reached BRL 310 million in average balance. Account opening NPS jumped from 34 to 57, while virtual card issuance shrank from four hours to six minutes.

Specifically on decisions: 79% of decisions (two-way door) were approved in under 24h vs. 6 weeks before; 94% of two-way door decisions were correct (only 6 rollbacks needed out of 99 decisions); saved 147 person-days in unnecessary committees. Credit risk stayed 0.4 p.p. below the traditional portfolio and there were zero critical incidents. The SeDR mechanism was replicated across five other Bradesco programs and became the corporate policy for initiatives above BRL 50 million.
en.l:
The main lesson from this case transformed my management approach: speed requires visible mechanisms and objective guardrails.

The SeDR framework revolutionized my decision management: (1) 80% of decisions are two-way door and deserve speed, not perfection; (2) Classifying decisions BEFORE discussing speeds up meetings by 60%; (3) Reversibility criterion (<30 days, <20% cost) is more useful than impact severity; (4) Recording two-way door decisions with reasoning enables fast rollback if needed.

Since then I launch every program with a two-way door matrix, a minimum telemetry dashboard, and a 24-hour SLA for reversible calls. I applied SeDR in 3 subsequent projects (Huawei, Unimed, Sicredi) with average 40% reduction in decision cycle. The same toolkit later enabled Unimed pilots to exit discovery in 45 days with controlled risk.

fups.q: Como voce definiu 'dados suficientes' vs. 'analise infinita' para decidir em 11 meses? Qual seu framework?
fups.a: Usei 'Decision Quality Threshold': para cada decisao, defini (1) Custo de erro (se errar, quanto perdemos?), (2) Custo de atraso (cada mes de espera, quanto perdemos em market share?). Se custo de atraso maior que custo de erro, era hora de agir. Exemplo: escolha de core bancario tinha custo de erro alto (R$8M migracao se errar) e baixo custo de atraso (escolher em 2 vs. 4 meses nao muda competicao) entao analisei 4 meses. Escolha de cor do app tinha baixo custo de erro (mudar em 1 semana) e alto custo de atraso (cada dia atrasava launch) entao decidi em 2 dias com A/B test de prototipos. Esse framework me fez rejeitar solicitacao do Marketing de 6 meses de pesquisa de UX: custo de atraso seria perder 180 mil leads (R$54M em saldo projetado).
fups.q_en: How did you define 'sufficient data' vs. 'analysis paralysis' to decide in 11 months? What's your framework?
fups.a_en: I used 'Decision Quality Threshold': for each decision, I defined (1) Cost of error (if wrong, how much do we lose?), (2) Cost of delay (each month waiting, how much market share do we lose?). If cost of delay greater than cost of error, it was time to act. Example: core banking choice had high cost of error (R$8M migration if wrong) and low cost of delay (choosing in 2 vs. 4 months doesn't change competition) so I analyzed for 4 months. App color choice had low cost of error (change in 1 week) and high cost of delay (each day delayed launch) so I decided in 2 days with A/B test of prototypes. This framework made me reject Marketing's request for 6 months of UX research: cost of delay would be losing 180k leads (R$54M in projected balance).

fups.q: Como voce classifica uma decisao como two-way door vs. one-way door? Quais criterios usa?
fups.a: Uso 3 criterios: (1) Reversibilidade: posso voltar atras em menos de 30 dias sem custo proibitivo?; (2) Impacto: se errar, o custo de rollback e menor que 20% do custo total?; (3) Dependencias: outros sistemas ou times dependem dessa decisao ser permanente? Se sim em 2 dos 3, e two-way door. Exemplo: escolha de provider de SMS e two-way (posso trocar em 2 semanas, custo R$8k), escolha de core bancario e one-way (migracao custaria R$8M e 18 meses). Aplico essa matriz ANTES de agendar reuniao de decisao, economizando 60% do tempo em discussoes desnecessarias.
fups.q_en: How do you classify a decision as two-way door vs. one-way door? What criteria do you use?
fups.a_en: I use 3 criteria: (1) Reversibility: can I reverse in under 30 days without prohibitive cost?; (2) Impact: if wrong, rollback cost is less than 20% of total cost?; (3) Dependencies: do other systems or teams depend on this decision being permanent? If yes on 2 of 3, it's two-way door. Example: SMS provider choice is two-way (can switch in 2 weeks, cost R$8k), core banking choice is one-way (migration would cost R$8M and 18 months). I apply this matrix BEFORE scheduling a decision meeting, saving 60% of time on unnecessary discussions.

fups.q: Que trade-offs voce bloqueou para proteger o prazo?
fups.a: Eu cito as 11 features adiadas, os savings de 9 sprints e o impacto positivo no NPS.
fups.q_en: Which trade-offs did you block to protect the timeline?
fups.a_en: I cite the 11 postponed features, nine-sprint savings, and the positive NPS impact.

fups.q: Voce teve alguma decisao two-way door que descobriu ser one-way door depois? Como lidou?
fups.a: Sim. A escolha de design system (Material UI vs. Bootstrap) foi classificada como two-way door (podemos trocar). Mas apos 4 meses, 78 componentes customizados estavam acoplados ao Material UI. Custo de migracao seria 6 semanas-squad. Aprendi: para decisoes arquiteturais, adicionar criterio 'velocidade de lock-in' - se uso cresce mais de 20 componentes por mes, reclassificar como one-way door e fazer analise profunda. Depois disso, adicionei gate de revisao no mes 2 para decisoes arquiteturais. No Next, esse aprendizado me fez revisar a decisao de mensageria (Kafka) no mes 3, quando ainda tinhamos apenas 12 topicos - confirmamos que estava correta, mas se fosse mudar seria naquele momento.
fups.q_en: Did you have any two-way door decision that turned out to be one-way door later? How did you handle it?
fups.a_en: Yes. Design system choice (Material UI vs. Bootstrap) was classified as two-way door (we can switch). But after 4 months, 78 custom components were coupled to Material UI. Migration cost would be 6 squad-weeks. I learned: for architectural decisions, add 'velocity of lock-in' criterion - if usage grows more than 20 components per month, reclassify as one-way door and do deep analysis. After that, I added month 2 review gate for architectural decisions. At Next, this learning made me review the messaging decision (Kafka) in month 3, when we only had 12 topics - we confirmed it was correct, but if we were to change it would be at that moment.

fups.q: Voce teve pressao para agir SEM dados suficientes? Como resistiu e qual foi o minimo de dados necessarios?
fups.a: Sim. VP de Marketing queria lancar cartao de credito no mes 8 sem dados de default rate (modelo de risco ainda em treinamento com apenas 4 meses de dados). Resisti criando 'Risk Gate': identifiquei que precisavamos de minimo 6 meses de dados historicos para ter 80% de confianca no modelo de risco (se nao, poderiamos ter default rate de 15% vs. 3% esperado igual a R$45M de perda). Negociei: lancamos cartao no mes 10 (atraso de 2 meses), mas com modelo calibrado. Resultado: default rate foi 3.2% (dentro do esperado). Aprendi: definir 'minimum confidence threshold' para decisoes de alto risco. Para decisoes com impacto financeiro maior que R$10M, exijo 80% de confianca estatistica; para decisoes two-way door com impacto menor que R$500k, aceito 60% de confianca e monitoro de perto.
fups.q_en: Did you face pressure to act WITHOUT sufficient data? How did you resist and what was the minimum data needed?
fups.a_en: Yes. VP of Marketing wanted to launch credit card in month 8 without default rate data (risk model still training with only 4 months of data). I resisted by creating 'Risk Gate': I identified we needed minimum 6 months of historical data to have 80% confidence in risk model (otherwise, we could have default rate of 15% vs. 3% expected equals R$45M loss). I negotiated: we launched card in month 10 (2-month delay), but with calibrated model. Result: default rate was 3.2% (within expected). I learned: define 'minimum confidence threshold' for high-risk decisions. For decisions with financial impact greater than R$10M, I require 80% statistical confidence; for two-way door decisions with impact less than R$500k, I accept 60% confidence and monitor closely.

fups.q: Como voce convenceu o CRO a liberar o piloto KYC light?
fups.a: Eu relato a analise de inadimplencia, os limites de rollback e os gatilhos de 4%.
fups.q_en: How did you convince the CRO to approve the light KYC pilot?
fups.a_en: I share the delinquency analysis, rollback limits, and 4% triggers.

fups.q: De que forma voce protegeu a experiencia do cliente durante o corte de campos?
fups.a: Eu conto como testei fluxos A/B com 1.500 clientes beta e medi tempo de abertura e CSAT.
fups.q_en: How did you protect customer experience while trimming fields?
fups.a_en: I describe the 1,500-customer A/B test measuring time-to-open and CSAT.

fups.q: Como voce convenceu stakeholders conservadores a aceitar decisoes rapidas two-way door?
fups.a: Criei 'Reversibility Index': para cada decisao two-way door, documentava (1) Tempo de rollback (ex: 48h), (2) Custo de rollback (ex: R$12k), (3) Impacto cliente durante rollback (ex: feature offline por 6h). Apresentava isso em 1 slide antes da decisao. Exemplo: integracao ClearSale tinha Reversibility Index de 48h slash R$15k slash 6h offline - VP aprovou em 4 horas. Tambem criei 'rollback playbook' com 5 passos pre-documentados: (1) detectar problema, (2) avaliar severidade, (3) executar script de rollback, (4) comunicar clientes afetados, (5) post-mortem em 24h. Apos 6 meses, 94% de acerto em two-way doors validou abordagem, e VP passou a aprovar via Slack sem reuniao.
fups.q_en: How did you convince conservative stakeholders to accept rapid two-way door decisions?
fups.a_en: I created 'Reversibility Index': for each two-way door decision, I documented (1) Rollback time (e.g., 48h), (2) Rollback cost (e.g., R$12k), (3) Customer impact during rollback (e.g., feature offline for 6h). Presented this in 1 slide before decision. Example: ClearSale integration had Reversibility Index of 48h slash R$15k slash 6h offline - VP approved in 4 hours. Also created 'rollback playbook' with 5 pre-documented steps: (1) detect problem, (2) assess severity, (3) execute rollback script, (4) communicate affected customers, (5) post-mortem in 24h. After 6 months, 94% success rate in two-way doors validated approach, and VP started approving via Slack without meetings.

fups.q: Quais eram os sinais leading que voce monitorava quatro vezes ao dia?
fups.a: Eu listo latencia de pagamento, erros documentais, uso do cartao virtual e filas de suporte.
fups.q_en: Which leading signals did you track four times a day?
fups.a_en: I list payment latency, document errors, virtual card usage, and support queues.

fups.q: Que resultados tangiveis sustentaram o go-live antecipado?
fups.a: Eu reforco os 1,2 milhao de clientes, NPS 57 e saldo medio de R$310 mi.
fups.q_en: What tangible results sustained the early go-live?
fups.a_en: I highlight 1.2M customers, NPS 57, and BRL 310M average balance.

fups.q: De que modo o mecanismo foi escalado para outros programas?
fups.a: Eu detalho o playbook SeDR, os OKRs adotados e o treinamento de 140 gestores.
fups.q_en: How was the mechanism scaled to other programs?
fups.a_en: I outline the SeDR playbook, adopted OKRs, and training of 140 managers.

fups.q: Qual foi o maior aprendizado pessoal desse ciclo?
fups.a: Eu mostro como uso matriz two-way door e telemetria minima em todo novo programa.
fups.q_en: What was your biggest personal learning from this cycle?
fups.a_en: I explain how I now start every program with a two-way door matrix and minimum telemetry.

The biggest blocker wasn't technology—it was the institutional culture of '3 committees and 6 weeks for everything'. No one had differentiated reversible from irreversible decisions. Stakes were lethal: lose R$310M in projected first-year balance, watch Nubank dominate our target audience (18-35 years), and see my career as innovation leader go down the drain. I created the SeDR (Speedy Decision Review): a revolutionary framework to classify decisions as two-way door (reversible, low rollback cost) vs. one-way door (irreversible, high impact). I identified that 79% of the 126 mapped decisions were two-way door and could be made in under 24h. This framework broke 70 years of Bradesco institutional slowness paradigm.
en.t: The critical challenge I faced was transforming a culture of slowness into controlled speed. I was the single-threaded owner for Product and Technology, empowered to define scope, cadence, and risk posture. My personal mandate was to compress time-to-market to 11 months without breaking compliance or the customer journey.
en.a:
My approach was to create a permanent rapid-decision mechanism with risk control.

I created a daily decision room with eight key leaders and introduced the "SeDR" (Speedy Decision Review) mechanism that I chaired. I classified 126 decisions as two-way or one-way; 79% were cleared within 24 hours. For two-way door decisions, I created a fast-track: 1-page presentation, 3 criteria (customer impact, reversibility <30 days, rollback cost <20% of total), approval within 24h. Example: ClearSale integration (antifraud) was approved in 9 hours because customer impact was high, but we could switch providers in 2 weeks if needed - rollback cost would be only R$15k (1.2% of budget).

For one-way door decisions, I required deep analysis: 3 scenarios, 5-year impact, exit strategy, VP+CTO approval. Example: core banking choice (Temenos) took 4 weeks of analysis because migration would cost R$8M and 18 months. I negotiated directly with the CRO a low-risk onboarding pilot across five customer segments covering 42% of the target base.

I rewired the onboarding funnel, stripping 17 redundant fields, and integrated ClearSale fraud scoring in nine days, cutting manual review from 82% to 41%. I defined rollback triggers whenever document errors exceeded 4% in any hour. I built a live telemetry dashboard with the payments squad and personally checked it four times per day, tracking virtual card SLA, settlement latency, and real-time NPS. Using that command center I greenlit 32 feature toggles and halted 11 scope requests that would have delayed the MVP.
en.r:
The measurable impact for customers — 420k leads in pipeline transformed into 1.2 million active customers — was transformative.

Next went live in month 11, seven months ahead of the original roadmap. Digital onboarding dropped from 27 days to 10 minutes and abandonment fell from 38% to 9%. In the first 12 months we activated 1.2 million customers and reached BRL 310 million in average balance. Account opening NPS jumped from 34 to 57, while virtual card issuance shrank from four hours to six minutes.

Specifically on decisions: 79% of decisions (two-way door) were approved in under 24h vs. 6 weeks before; 94% of two-way door decisions were correct (only 6 rollbacks needed out of 99 decisions); saved 147 person-days in unnecessary committees. Credit risk stayed 0.4 p.p. below the traditional portfolio and there were zero critical incidents. The SeDR mechanism was replicated across five other Bradesco programs and became the corporate policy for initiatives above BRL 50 million.
en.l:
The main lesson from this case transformed my management approach: speed requires visible mechanisms and objective guardrails.

The SeDR framework revolutionized my decision management: (1) 80% of decisions are two-way door and deserve speed, not perfection; (2) Classifying decisions BEFORE discussing speeds up meetings by 60%; (3) Reversibility criterion (<30 days, <20% cost) is more useful than impact severity; (4) Recording two-way door decisions with reasoning enables fast rollback if needed.

Since then I launch every program with a two-way door matrix, a minimum telemetry dashboard, and a 24-hour SLA for reversible calls. I applied SeDR in 3 subsequent projects (Huawei, Unimed, Sicredi) with average 40% reduction in decision cycle. The same toolkit later enabled Unimed pilots to exit discovery in 45 days with controlled risk.

fups.q: Como voce definiu 'dados suficientes' vs. 'analise infinita' para decidir em 11 meses? Qual seu framework?
fups.a: Usei 'Decision Quality Threshold': para cada decisao, defini (1) Custo de erro (se errar, quanto perdemos?), (2) Custo de atraso (cada mes de espera, quanto perdemos em market share?). Se custo de atraso maior que custo de erro, era hora de agir. Exemplo: escolha de core bancario tinha custo de erro alto (R$8M migracao se errar) e baixo custo de atraso (escolher em 2 vs. 4 meses nao muda competicao) entao analisei 4 meses. Escolha de cor do app tinha baixo custo de erro (mudar em 1 semana) e alto custo de atraso (cada dia atrasava launch) entao decidi em 2 dias com A/B test de prototipos. Esse framework me fez rejeitar solicitacao do Marketing de 6 meses de pesquisa de UX: custo de atraso seria perder 180 mil leads (R$54M em saldo projetado).
fups.q_en: How did you define 'sufficient data' vs. 'analysis paralysis' to decide in 11 months? What's your framework?
fups.a_en: I used 'Decision Quality Threshold': for each decision, I defined (1) Cost of error (if wrong, how much do we lose?), (2) Cost of delay (each month waiting, how much market share do we lose?). If cost of delay greater than cost of error, it was time to act. Example: core banking choice had high cost of error (R$8M migration if wrong) and low cost of delay (choosing in 2 vs. 4 months doesn't change competition) so I analyzed for 4 months. App color choice had low cost of error (change in 1 week) and high cost of delay (each day delayed launch) so I decided in 2 days with A/B test of prototypes. This framework made me reject Marketing's request for 6 months of UX research: cost of delay would be losing 180k leads (R$54M in projected balance).

fups.q: Como voce classifica uma decisao como two-way door vs. one-way door? Quais criterios usa?
fups.a: Uso 3 criterios: (1) Reversibilidade: posso voltar atras em menos de 30 dias sem custo proibitivo?; (2) Impacto: se errar, o custo de rollback e menor que 20% do custo total?; (3) Dependencias: outros sistemas ou times dependem dessa decisao ser permanente? Se sim em 2 dos 3, e two-way door. Exemplo: escolha de provider de SMS e two-way (posso trocar em 2 semanas, custo R$8k), escolha de core bancario e one-way (migracao custaria R$8M e 18 meses). Aplico essa matriz ANTES de agendar reuniao de decisao, economizando 60% do tempo em discussoes desnecessarias.
fups.q_en: How do you classify a decision as two-way door vs. one-way door? What criteria do you use?
fups.a_en: I use 3 criteria: (1) Reversibility: can I reverse in under 30 days without prohibitive cost?; (2) Impact: if wrong, rollback cost is less than 20% of total cost?; (3) Dependencies: do other systems or teams depend on this decision being permanent? If yes on 2 of 3, it's two-way door. Example: SMS provider choice is two-way (can switch in 2 weeks, cost R$8k), core banking choice is one-way (migration would cost R$8M and 18 months). I apply this matrix BEFORE scheduling a decision meeting, saving 60% of time on unnecessary discussions.

fups.q: Que trade-offs voce bloqueou para proteger o prazo?
fups.a: Eu cito as 11 features adiadas, os savings de 9 sprints e o impacto positivo no NPS.
fups.q_en: Which trade-offs did you block to protect the timeline?
fups.a_en: I cite the 11 postponed features, nine-sprint savings, and the positive NPS impact.

fups.q: Voce teve alguma decisao two-way door que descobriu ser one-way door depois? Como lidou?
fups.a: Sim. A escolha de design system (Material UI vs. Bootstrap) foi classificada como two-way door (podemos trocar). Mas apos 4 meses, 78 componentes customizados estavam acoplados ao Material UI. Custo de migracao seria 6 semanas-squad. Aprendi: para decisoes arquiteturais, adicionar criterio 'velocidade de lock-in' - se uso cresce mais de 20 componentes por mes, reclassificar como one-way door e fazer analise profunda. Depois disso, adicionei gate de revisao no mes 2 para decisoes arquiteturais. No Next, esse aprendizado me fez revisar a decisao de mensageria (Kafka) no mes 3, quando ainda tinhamos apenas 12 topicos - confirmamos que estava correta, mas se fosse mudar seria naquele momento.
fups.q_en: Did you have any two-way door decision that turned out to be one-way door later? How did you handle it?
fups.a_en: Yes. Design system choice (Material UI vs. Bootstrap) was classified as two-way door (we can switch). But after 4 months, 78 custom components were coupled to Material UI. Migration cost would be 6 squad-weeks. I learned: for architectural decisions, add 'velocity of lock-in' criterion - if usage grows more than 20 components per month, reclassify as one-way door and do deep analysis. After that, I added month 2 review gate for architectural decisions. At Next, this learning made me review the messaging decision (Kafka) in month 3, when we only had 12 topics - we confirmed it was correct, but if we were to change it would be at that moment.

fups.q: Voce teve pressao para agir SEM dados suficientes? Como resistiu e qual foi o minimo de dados necessarios?
fups.a: Sim. VP de Marketing queria lancar cartao de credito no mes 8 sem dados de default rate (modelo de risco ainda em treinamento com apenas 4 meses de dados). Resisti criando 'Risk Gate': identifiquei que precisavamos de minimo 6 meses de dados historicos para ter 80% de confianca no modelo de risco (se nao, poderiamos ter default rate de 15% vs. 3% esperado igual a R$45M de perda). Negociei: lancamos cartao no mes 10 (atraso de 2 meses), mas com modelo calibrado. Resultado: default rate foi 3.2% (dentro do esperado). Aprendi: definir 'minimum confidence threshold' para decisoes de alto risco. Para decisoes com impacto financeiro maior que R$10M, exijo 80% de confianca estatistica; para decisoes two-way door com impacto menor que R$500k, aceito 60% de confianca e monitoro de perto.
fups.q_en: Did you face pressure to act WITHOUT sufficient data? How did you resist and what was the minimum data needed?
fups.a_en: Yes. VP of Marketing wanted to launch credit card in month 8 without default rate data (risk model still training with only 4 months of data). I resisted by creating 'Risk Gate': I identified we needed minimum 6 months of historical data to have 80% confidence in risk model (otherwise, we could have default rate of 15% vs. 3% expected equals R$45M loss). I negotiated: we launched card in month 10 (2-month delay), but with calibrated model. Result: default rate was 3.2% (within expected). I learned: define 'minimum confidence threshold' for high-risk decisions. For decisions with financial impact greater than R$10M, I require 80% statistical confidence; for two-way door decisions with impact less than R$500k, I accept 60% confidence and monitor closely.

fups.q: Como voce convenceu o CRO a liberar o piloto KYC light?
fups.a: Eu relato a analise de inadimplencia, os limites de rollback e os gatilhos de 4%.
fups.q_en: How did you convince the CRO to approve the light KYC pilot?
fups.a_en: I share the delinquency analysis, rollback limits, and 4% triggers.

fups.q: De que forma voce protegeu a experiencia do cliente durante o corte de campos?
fups.a: Eu conto como testei fluxos A/B com 1.500 clientes beta e medi tempo de abertura e CSAT.
fups.q_en: How did you protect customer experience while trimming fields?
fups.a_en: I describe the 1,500-customer A/B test measuring time-to-open and CSAT.

fups.q: Como voce convenceu stakeholders conservadores a aceitar decisoes rapidas two-way door?
fups.a: Criei 'Reversibility Index': para cada decisao two-way door, documentava (1) Tempo de rollback (ex: 48h), (2) Custo de rollback (ex: R$12k), (3) Impacto cliente durante rollback (ex: feature offline por 6h). Apresentava isso em 1 slide antes da decisao. Exemplo: integracao ClearSale tinha Reversibility Index de 48h slash R$15k slash 6h offline - VP aprovou em 4 horas. Tambem criei 'rollback playbook' com 5 passos pre-documentados: (1) detectar problema, (2) avaliar severidade, (3) executar script de rollback, (4) comunicar clientes afetados, (5) post-mortem em 24h. Apos 6 meses, 94% de acerto em two-way doors validou abordagem, e VP passou a aprovar via Slack sem reuniao.
fups.q_en: How did you convince conservative stakeholders to accept rapid two-way door decisions?
fups.a_en: I created 'Reversibility Index': for each two-way door decision, I documented (1) Rollback time (e.g., 48h), (2) Rollback cost (e.g., R$12k), (3) Customer impact during rollback (e.g., feature offline for 6h). Presented this in 1 slide before decision. Example: ClearSale integration had Reversibility Index of 48h slash R$15k slash 6h offline - VP approved in 4 hours. Also created 'rollback playbook' with 5 pre-documented steps: (1) detect problem, (2) assess severity, (3) execute rollback script, (4) communicate affected customers, (5) post-mortem in 24h. After 6 months, 94% success rate in two-way doors validated approach, and VP started approving via Slack without meetings.

fups.q: Quais eram os sinais leading que voce monitorava quatro vezes ao dia?
fups.a: Eu listo latencia de pagamento, erros documentais, uso do cartao virtual e filas de suporte.
fups.q_en: Which leading signals did you track four times a day?
fups.a_en: I list payment latency, document errors, virtual card usage, and support queues.

fups.q: Que resultados tangiveis sustentaram o go-live antecipado?
fups.a: Eu reforco os 1,2 milhao de clientes, NPS 57 e saldo medio de R$310 mi.
fups.q_en: What tangible results sustained the early go-live?
fups.a_en: I highlight 1.2M customers, NPS 57, and BRL 310M average balance.

fups.q: De que modo o mecanismo foi escalado para outros programas?
fups.a: Eu detalho o playbook SeDR, os OKRs adotados e o treinamento de 140 gestores.
fups.q_en: How was the mechanism scaled to other programs?
fups.a_en: I outline the SeDR playbook, adopted OKRs, and training of 140 managers.

fups.q: Qual foi o maior aprendizado pessoal desse ciclo?
fups.a: Eu mostro como uso matriz two-way door e telemetria minima em todo novo programa.
fups.q_en: What was your biggest personal learning from this cycle?
fups.a_en: I explain how I now start every program with a two-way door matrix and minimum telemetry.
